clinical_study.brief_title: My Pathway to Healing: Adaptation and Testing of a Common Elements Treatment Approach to Address Trauma, Suicide Ideation and Substance Abuse
clinical_study.official_title: My Pathway to Healing: Adaptation and Testing of a Common Elements Treatment Approach to Address Trauma, Suicide Ideation and Substance Abuse

lead_sponsor.agency: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

clinical_study.source: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this project is to test the effectiveness, feasibility and acceptability of a common elements intervention delivered by community mental health workers for adults with a history of adverse childhood experiences. "Common elements" interventions build cognitive, emotional, interpersonal and behavioral skills to help address trauma-related distress and build resilience. This will be accomplished using a wait-list controlled randomized control trial with Apache adults ages 18-65 with recent suicide ideation and/or binge substance use.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a mixed-methods study with qualitative data informing adaptation and evaluation of a common elements intervention delivered by community mental health specialists, named "My Pathway to Healing."
Apache partners selected a wait-list randomized control trial, as it is a rigorous study design for understanding whether an intervention works and was endorsed by the community, to evaluate the effectiveness of the My Pathway to Healing intervention delivered by community mental health specialists (CMHS). This intervention consists of an initial assessment to determine treatment priorities and safety. It integrates psychoeducation and addresses safety (when identified as a problem area). It can also include teaching relaxation, cognitive coping, exposure-trauma memories, exposure-live, cognitive restructuring, behavioral activation, and problem solving. The intervention used in the tested arm of our study will be adapted to the specific context and culture of White Mountain Apache.
Those randomized into the My Pathway to Healing group will receive 5-15 hour-long sessions with a community mental health specialist, taking place over 12 weeks. The exact number of sessions will depend on presentation and symptom level using a stepped care approach where participants receive only what they need, but the provider can provide additional sessions if needed (i.e., increased element dosage; additional optional elements for specific issues). Those randomized into the wait-list control will continue to receive the standard case management via the Apache surveillance system. These wait-list control participants will be asked to wait until all N=50 My Pathway to Healing participants have started the program and then will be offered the program on a rolling basis based on availability of providers
Participants, will be asked to partake in 5 study assessments. For intervention participants these assessments will take place at: baseline, after their last intervention session (endline) and 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-endline. For control participants, these assessments will take place at: baseline, 12 weeks post-baseline (the maximum time the intervention would last; will be referred to as an endline) and 4, 8 and 12 weeks post-endline. These assessment visits will be conducted by the Research Program Assistants who will serve as the independent evaluators. Assessments will take approximately 45-90 minutes to complete.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Investigators will use a wait-list controlled design.
study_design_info.masking_description: Individuals conducting assessments with participants will be blinded to their randomization status.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Post Traumatic Stress Symptoms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
primary_outcome.description: Post traumatic stress symptoms will be measured using part 4 of the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire (HTQ) based on Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) criteria for post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The scale ranges from 0 (Not at All) to 4 (Extremely). A higher score indicates a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: The IDSS will be used to measure depression symptom severity. The scale ranges from 0-3. A higher score indicates a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Hopkins Symptom Checklist for Anxiety to measure severity of anxiety symptoms. This scale will range from 1-4. A higher score indicates a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Alcohol, Smoking and Substance Involvement Screening Test (ASSIST) to measure alcohol and substance use. This 15-item questionnaire screens for all levels of problems or risky substance use (alcohol, illegal drugs, and prescription drugs). A risk score is provided for each substance, and scores are grouped into low, moderate, or high risk, providing a comprehensive view of substance use. This scale ranges from 0-27+. A total score of 0-3 indicates low risk/no intervention. A total score of 4-26 indicates moderate risk/brief intervention. A total score of 27+ indicates high risk/more intensive treatment.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Weekly from baseline to 12 weeks post baseline (during intervention sessions), Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the timeline follow-back to measure alcohol and substance use in the past three months. Timeline follow-back is a calendar based self-report measure that asks the number and type of substance used everyday in the past 7 days-3 months. It will be used at every time point and during every My Pathway to Healing session as both a research tool and a motivation advice feedback tool.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will ask several questions to track number of suicidal behavior incidents and severity. This is not a scale. A series of 4 questions assessing suicide risk (i.e. "Do you think of killing yourself," "Do you have a plan," "Do you have a way to carry out the plan," "Have you ever tried killing yourself before," etc.). If participant answers yes to any questions then there are follow up questions and a facilitator must develop a safety plan with the participant. The facilitator must contact the supervisor (trained clinician) within 24 hours to review the plan.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Trait Hope Scale to measure levels of hopefulness. This scale ranges from 0-96. A higher scale indicates a higher perceived level of hope (i.e. positive outcome).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use a communal mastery questionnaire to measure self-efficacy and knowledge of communal resources. Scores will range from 0-40. A higher score indicates a more positive outcome.

Investigators will use the Historical Loss Scale to measure types of historical discrimination and trauma. Investigators will first ask 13 questions regarding how often participant think of various historical events on a never (1) to several times a day (6). Investigators will ask 7 additional questions regarding how much participants are connected with others in their tribe on a scale of strongly agree (1) to strong disagree (4). The first subscale, a higher score indicates a worse outcome (i.e. more affected by historical trauma. The second subscale. A higher score indicates a worse outcome.

Investigators will use an adapted version of the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) ACEs module.The ACEs scale ranges from 0-21. A higher score indicates more adverse childhood experiences (i.e. worse outcome).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Severity of Violence Against Women Scale. Investigators will use an adapted version of this scale for men. The purpose of this scale is to measure the number of violent incidents over time. For women, the scale ranges from 0-138 and 0-48 for men. For both men and women, a higher score indicates a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Index of Psychological Abuse to track incidents of emotional abuse over time. Each item is asked on a scale of 1 (never) to 4 (often). A higher score indicates a worse outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale to measure level of self-esteem. The scale ranges from 0-30. A higher score indicates a higher level of self-esteem (i.e. positive outcome).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators will use the Brief Cope Measure to assess a participant's ability to cope with stress in their life. The scale ranges from 0-8. A higher score indicates a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Endline (12 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 1 (16 weeks after baseline), Follow Up 2 (20 weeks after baseline) Follow Up 3 (24 weeks after baseline)
secondary_outcome.description: Investigators developed a locally relevant functioning scale from primary outcome data, in which participants were asked about tasks and activities that are important for people to do for themselves, their families and the community. The most frequently mentioned responses are combined to create the scale. The scale ranges from 0-4. A higher score indicates a worse outcome. This approach has been used widely in culturally diverse contexts internationally.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Weekly from baseline to 12 weeks post baseline (during intervention sessions)
secondary_outcome.description: The Client Monitoring Form will be used to track the mental health and well-being of intervention participants on a week-to-week basis. There are 17-questions that measure both presence and severity of symptoms commonly associated with depression and anxiety. Questions are asked on a scale of 0 (None of the time) to 3 (Almost all of the time). A higher score indicates a worse outcome. Additionally, clients are asked if they are utilizing other mental health services, and screened for suicidal and homicidal ideation, with reporters mandated to record what actions were taken in reaction to recording any such ideation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Post-Training Knowledge Tests for Supervisors & Community mental Health Specialists
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 week after training, after piloting intervention (approximately 6 months after training), and 9 months after training
secondary_outcome.description: A 29 question assessment will be used to assess post-training knowledge of supervisors and community health specialists. This assessment has been used in previous common elements treatment approach (CETA) trials. It includes a combination of multiple choice, fill in the blank, open ended, and case response questions. Knowledge tests are often used as an evaluation of training to see if training increases the knowledge of trainees. This is not a scale

secondary_outcome.measure: Community mental health specialist competency of intervention delivery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1 week after training, after piloting intervention (approximately 6 months after training), and 9 months after training
secondary_outcome.description: The Enhancing Assessment of Common Therapeutic Factors (ENACT) Scale will be used to assess community mental health specialist competency of intervention delivery. It has been used previously in low-resource and culturally-diverse settings. It utilizes standardized role plays 40 Scores range from 18 to 54, with >36 indicating moderate competency.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults aged 18-65
- Suicide ideation or binge alcohol and/or drug use within past 90 days confirmed by the Apache suicide surveillance system
- Experienced >3 adverse childhood experiences
- Native American
- Reside on or near the Fort Apache Indian Reservation.
- An average score of 1 or above on a measure of symptoms of posttraumatic stress
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to provide informed consent
- Have a serious developmental disorder
- Have active psychosis
- Had a suicide attempt in the past 3 months
